thread.title: Mercedes keen on driverless cars
thread.title_full: Mercedes keen on driverless cars | Business Spectator

author: David Swan
title: Mercedes keen on driverless cars
text:
German automaker Mercedes is reportedly looking to build a fleet of on-demand driverless luxury vehicles, in a move that would see it take on the likes of Uber and Google.
Mercedes, which is owned by German multinational Daimler, is eyeing a segment of the population that is more interested in on-demand transportation than actually owning a vehicle, Daimler CEO Dieter Zetsche told Reuters, describing it as “a concrete development goal of ours.”
Daimler has a car sharing service already, car2go, which allows users to rent nearby vehicles owned by Daimler through a smartphone app.
However, Mr Zetsche said he was more interested in the possibilities offered by driverless vehicles.
“It would be even more convenient if the car came to you autonomously,” he toldReuters.
“And it would be extremely practical if the car2go appeared without needing to be prompted, once my appointment in the calendar had come to an end.”
Uber has reportedly been testing self-driving technology for some time now, however, the firm’s senior vice president of policy and strategy David Plouffe, who served as the campaign manager of Barack Obama’s successful 2008 presidential campaign, told The Australian it was a “long way off.”
“Everyone’s starting to look at autonomous technology”, he said at a briefing in the company’s San Francisco offices.
“And that’s very exciting. We’re working on a lot of things; our mapping’s getting better, sensor technology is improving and so is safety. Eventually there’ll be no more accidents. But that’s quite a ways off.”
Mr Zetsche told Reuters that his company’s current car rental services, which have been operating for some time now, and opportunities related to autonomous vehicles would be a strong economic driver for Daimler.
“I think you don’t need too much imagination to see that by combining these strengths, attractive business models are possible in future,” Mr Zetsche said.
Earlier this year Daimler, in conjunction with fellow German auto firms Audi and BMW, acquired Nokia’s mapping division HERE.
Google has also been working hard on driverless cars, and says it plans to have automated cars on the road by 2020, while Tesla is also developing its own driverless technology.
In related news, driverless cars will hit Australian roads for the first time in November this year, with the South Australian government conducting a trial.
Those trials, which will be held on the Southern Expressway, at Tonsley Innovation Park and also at Adelaide Airport, will establish how driverless technology needs to be engineered and manufactured for Australian driving behaviour, climate, road conditions, markings, surfaces and roadside signage.
David Swan travelled to San Francisco as a guest of Salesforce.
